tacker/objects/vnf_lcm_op_occs.py.message: According to the SPEC of Support ETSI NFV-SOL based error-handling operation, the "metadata" support for fail operation is N. Can you tell me why in this patch you need to add "metadata" ?

> According to the SPEC of Support ETSI NFV-SOL based error-handling operation, the "metadata" support for fail operation is N. Can you tell me why in this patch you need to add "metadata" ?

Metadata added in the code is for VNFInfoModification and it is Y based on the specifications.

VNFInfoModification ➞ metadata --> Y
ResourceChanges ➞ AffectedVnfc ➞ metadata --> N
ResourceChanges ➞ AffectedVirtualLink ➞ metadata --> N
ResourceChanges ➞ AffectedVirtualStorage ➞ metadata --> N

Since this was added by another merged patch, we removed our changes and retained the metadata that was added from that patch already merged to master.
I understood. I missed Y of VNFInfoModifications.

manila/share/drivers/zadara/zadara.py.message:
Should this be fatal? Raising an exception here will cause all rules to be set to "error". 
If a rule wasn't present in the backend you could log it and return...

Observation: you are logging an error, but by not raising an exception, the Share Manager layer will believe your operation completed successfully, therefore you are ignoring the error. In that case, it makes more sense to be a warning, instead of an error.

Since you are deleting a rule that perhaps shouldn't be there in the first place (in the case of migration, it would have been added due to a different backend, and doesn't make sense in yours), it makes sense to ignore the error. Therefore warning level should be more appropriate, as this is not an error.

it would be useful to add a brief code comment here just to state that this is a special case for migration, where you want to delete and re-add all the rules.

Source: driver.py docstring:

``add_rules`` and ``delete_rules`` can be empty lists, in this
        situation, drivers should ensure that the rules present in
        ``access_rules`` are the same as those on the back end. One scenario
        where this situation is forced is when the access_level is changed for
        all existing rules (share migration and for readable replicas).

tripleo_ansible/ansible_plugins/action/t.message: should we just use artifact_urls which can be local and remote artifacts using different url schemes (i.e 'file://', 'http://')?
Really, user writing wrong file urls make it a different data type. That justification does not make any sense to me. But lets move on.
I think it makes sense according to RFC 8089, but alas lets move on.
we could but I'm not a fan of that approach. Separate input for a given data type seems like a better approach.
Not sure why you say different data types i.e they are urls, only the scheme differs. But this plugin is mostly for internal use, so we can have whatever we like.

They're different data types because the `file` scheme is generally written wrong by the end user, and I don't think we should be put that handling in our module to correct folks who've not read the RFC.

for example the following URI `file:///etc/hosts`
is really `file://localhost/etc/hosts`
and is typically written by users as `file://etc/hosts` -- this results in a relative path.

By keeping the different inputs we don't have to handle end-user assumptions or give the impression that the interface accepts more than `http`.
DOCUMENTATION does not talk about this option.

def check_vnf_status_and_error_point(action, status=None):

    def outer(f):

        def inner(self, context, vnf_instance, vnf, *args, **kw):
            initial_error_point = constants.ERR_PT_INITIAL
            vnf['current_error_point'] = initial_error_point

                    uuid=vnf['id'],
                    state=vnf['status'],
                    action=action,

We would like to explain in detail why we did this in our code:

current_statuses parameter is a required parameter, therefore it should always have a value.
The logging we have (L.625) before the "if" condition is just for debugging purposes, as to what value was prior to entering the "if" condition.
Our logging will show whether that the values will either be the following:
None, STATUSES(ACTIVE, INACTIVE, PENDING_CREATE, PENDING_HEAL, PENDING_SCALE, ..)

For the specific "if" condition (L.635), we are expecting the value is not None. Thus, we have an "if" condition specified. If a value other than None is received, there will be a checking for the vnf conflict state. However, if None is received, it will not perform such check.

manila/share/drivers/netapp/dataontap/cl.message:
Couple of issues here:

- Shouldn't you do this only after the older client is detached from the vserver? An error on line 1614 can leave an orphaned ldap client
- retrying the security service update can error out here since _create_ldap_client isn't idempotent.

In ONTAP, we can create as many ldap client configs as needed, but only one can be active in the SVM ('ldap-config-create' call). The decision for always creating the new ldap configuration first is because it is the operation that has more chance to fail, since user may provide a invalid IP/Server/User/Password parameter in the new security service.
It is very unlikely to happen an error different from OBJECTNOTFOUND in 'ldap-client-delete' operation, so I preffer to add a '_delete_ldap_client(new_security_service) in its rollback to delete the previously created config.
If we do invert these operations, we'll need to also revert the 'ldap-config-delete' operation in the rollbacks.

Do we care?
Can't this just be logged for an administrator to clean up?
You are right, we can just log a warning, since a ldap config cleanup may be needed.

Discussed briefly with Shyam https://github.com/ShyamsundarR who helped write the CSI driver's equivalent API. 

We need to monitor the clone's state using `fs clone status <vol_name> <clone_name> <group_name>` command until the clone is in "completed" or "failed" state. The clone state is in 'pending' state if an asynchronous cloner thread hasn't started cloning, or is 'in-progress' if an asynchronous cloner thread is doing the clone. The clone is going to take longer for larger shares to complete. I'm not sure how long we wait before we timeout, or how frequently we issue the `fs clone state` call.

The `fs snapshot clone` command triggers a recursive copy of the snapshot, where a libcephfs client traverses the tree and does a bulk copy as follows by the python code,
https://github.com/ceph/ceph/blob/v16.1.0/src/pybind/mgr/volumes/fs/async_cloner.py#L124


We can get the clone state by doing the following,
def _get_clone_state(self):
    argdict = {
        "vol_name": self.volname,
        "clone_name": share["id"]
    }
    if share['share_group_id'] is not None:
        argdict.update({"group_name": share["share_group_id"]})
    out = rados_command(self.rados_client, "fs clone status", argdict)
    return out['status']['state']

As discussed in Tom's patch https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/manila/+/780393, we need to determine if the share being removed is a CephFS subvolume or a snapshot-clone using `fs clone status` command.

If it's a clone and status is 'in-progress' or 'pending', we need to cancel the cloning. Then issue `fs subvolume rm --force' to remove the clone.

Lets think about this a bit.. This waiter is quite dangerous to add to a periodic task. The assumption on get_share_status is that it returns quickly.
All periodic tasks are meant to return as soon as possible because they're run on threads that get spawned at absolute regular intervals. 

So imagine this retry makes a 60-second (default value of "CONF.periodic_interval") periodic task wait for a couple of minutes - so while it is running two other calls will come into the driver to get_share_status() and if the status continues to be "pending" those threads are set to wait as well.

actions/cloud.py.message: Would it be worth running an evacuate against this host if there are still VMs present on it?

Dmitrii made some research on this topic and we discussed it when I was doing the initial implementation. I don't recall all the specifics but bottom line was that evacuating hosts is not so trivial and can cause some problems, including network and CPU load spikes (especially if there's a lot of VMs on the compute node). So rather than trying to be too clever, we limited this action to be able to run only on empty compute nodes.

I think we have a bit of crossover here on charm ownership of services - its fine for the nova-compute charm to disable/remove the nova-compute service from the cloud, but the networking service components need to be delegated in the same way to the appropriate subordinate charm - OVN_AGENTS makes a huge assumption that the cloud is actually using OVN.

I included "neutron agent" stuff because it was mentioned in the discussion in the original LP issue. My goal was to make this whole process (removing nova-compute unit) a single action. How would you like to see it implemented? Two actions (one on nova-compute and one on neutron agent) or can this be somehow automatized via relation?

> OVN_AGENTS makes a huge assumption that the cloud is actually using OVN.

OVN_AGENTS is actually used to determine whether the OVN or OVS is used.
I can't help but think you have to decide between using single or double quotes.

I admit that I'm sometimes inconsistent. I generally try to go for single quotes over double quotes (unless the string itself contains single quote).

However, the rest of the charm also mixes single and double quotes and Openstack Coding Guidelines (https://docs.openstack.org/charm-guide/latest/coding-guidelines.html) do not mention which is preferred, so I'd let this one pass.
delegate this to the networking driver specific subordinate charm.

The list method can get "host" and "binary" attributes.
https://github.com/openstack/python-novaclient/blob/master/novaclient/v2/services.py#L39
Done + fixed unit tests to match

I think list_agents can get **_params. One of them is the "host" attribute.
https://github.com/openstack/python-neutronclient/blob/master/neutronclient/v2_0/client.py#L1490

On a cloud with 200 compute nodes, and no neutron-gateways, each compute node will have a neutron-openvswitch-agent, a DHCP agent, a L3 agent and possibly a NIC agent (for SR-IOV capabilities)... 800 agents that could be filtered when running this in an action.
I removed this whole function in favor of using filtering parameters (+ fixed unit tests to match)
Wouldn't service_stop(OVN_HOST_SERVICE) work? If not, could we add a link to the documented (and recommended) procedure in a comment?

I'll have to redeploy the OS in serverstack to test this. In the meantime, I found this http://www.openvswitch.org/support/dist-docs/ovn-controller.8.html that says:

"exit   Causes ovn-controller to gracefully terminate."
afaik, starting already running service has no effect, so I feel like adding check like that is superfluous.

Are we sure that's the way it works? The service_resume helper func follows the approach I mentioned, but I'm fine leaving it as it is if "service_start" does not fail if the service is already running.
https://github.com/juju/charm-helpers/blob/master/charmhelpers/core/host.py#L215

service_start calls either `service <name> start` or `systemctl start <name>` under the hood. Repeated executions of `register-to-cloud` action do not result in error and this way we save one subprocess execution (because we don't need to run `systemctl status`).
I would leave this one as is.

I think the search method could help narrow the lookup.
https://github.com/openstack/python-novaclient/blob/master/novaclient/v2/hypervisors.py#L79

So, it seems that the `search()` isn't possible after all. For `search()` to return results with attribute `running_vms` we would have to use parameter `detailed=True` but that isn't available until nova api 2.53 and that's not available in mitaka release.

I'll add note to the code that once we no longer have to support trusty+mitaka, this can be changed to `search()`

search() returns also partial matches, so If you have nodes 'nova-compute-1' and 'nova-compute-10', searching for node 'nova-compute-1' would return both of these nodes in result.

I tried to use regexp like '^hostname$' but it didn't work as expected.

Yeah, you're right, but the list of parsed hypervisors should get reduced, at least. I'm thinking again about a cloud with 200 hypervisors, several racks with compute-1 to compute-16 on them, so the list of returned hypervisors would be 11*n_racks (worst case) vs the whole list?
Isn't it enough to just use `service_pause(OVN_AGENT_SERVICE)`?

There is more than one service associated with the ovn agent that needs to be shutdown. OVN_AGENT_SERRVICE (neutron-ovn-metadata-agent) is just on of them and is used to identify whether OVN or OVS is used on this nova-compute unit.

From my testing, running `ovn-appctl exit` achieves clean shutdown of the ovn agent.

This packages should be installed by the install hook, as the Nova compute services need to communicate with Keystone, the Nova API and the Neutron API.

I think those modules should be mocked in the unit tests.

The charm may rely on apt packages, which may have different versions depending on the Ubuntu and OpenStack release in use. "requirements.txt" (or wheelhouse.txt) would use the latest version available in PyPI, which is not the desired approach.

OTOH, if requirements.txt is only used for unit and func tests, I don't see why they are needed: func tests only deploy Juju models where tests happen; unit tests should be isolated and not use 3rd party libraries for testing.

By mocking imported clients, I was thinking of global mocking, yes. sys.modules[...] = mock.Mock()

Yes, they are already present on the units, but is it a bad thing to have them listed as dependency of the charm when the charm is explicitly using them?

Done
/ultilizes/utilizes
Done
This is not a requirement. I use a LB outside of kolla-ansible.
Currently, in Kolla-ansible architecture, HAProxy is default and recommend component in Kolla-ansible architecture for multinode deployment.
this can be solved with haproxy itself, draining connections to nodes before shutting down and restarting containers (serially). This was discussed at somepoint in the past, but no one did the work

Without this piece for haproxy when you restart a container you are breaking connections.

Which services are you speaking of specially. Neutron has full online upgrades, as well as nova. We don't currently do them in Kolla, but they have native support for that.

The only services that I can think this would be useful for would be mariadb and rabbitmq, but buffering rabbitmq is a bad idea in general. Since you are purposing _delaying_ the connection to mariadb with buffering, i don't see how that is different than having a retry in the application itself which currently happens.

My point is what is being shown in the video can be solved by utilizing haproxy to drain and restart the servers in serial without this buffering layer. The only reason any connections fail at all is because we aren't coordinating with haproxy while doing the upgrade. This buffering is simply hiding that but holding all connections.

Sam, we have tested the online upgrades features in Neutron, Nova, KeyStone. Neutron meet some downtimes when do online schema migrating as you can see in the first part of video. Nova and KeyStone did well with online upgrade. 

These above tests are normally for individual projects. In the whole system the total downtime is bigger. While you serially do online upgrade for each components, the requests sometimes can't reach the upgrading services.

Your point on using HAProxy is great idea, but HAProxy can not support for some projects that currently do not support online upgrade for DB or RPC versioning like Glance, Neutron, Heat. That's why we come with this approach.

As Sam Yaple said before, buffering in HAproxy can be avoided using admin socket in HAproxy, you can put a node in maintenance mode while waiting to end all requests to that node. This will avoid downtime on the API layer when the orchestration is properly done.

For the worker services, downtime cannot be avoided unless the service itself support zero-downtime upgrade as nova, keystone, neutron.
We're trying to reduce this downtime to zero with buffering layer.

You described zero-downtime on behalf of HAProxy, which mean services must have native zero-downtime upgrade support. The bp I'm proposing is targeted to zero-downtime upgrade even when services do not have native zero-downtime upgrade ability.
You are wrong, what i just described is zero downtime.
It will reduce the downtime but the goal of this bp is zero-downtime upgrade.
how?
I'm figuring out how to do this.
Their is no tracking information of how many services kolla implemente upgrade mechanism, So it would be better if put services names here.

We have upgrade action on every service, but it's offline upgrade and a few services in bp/apply-service-upgrade-procedure has rolling/minimal downtime/zero downtime upgrade capability from service itself.

An optional approach:

then you could avoid the below if/else statement and specify need_to_update_usages=need_to_update_usages instead
good idea!

we don't want to allow deletion of MANAGE_ERROR shares. Those should only be unmanaged.

The reason for that is that it will always invoke the driver's delete_share path, which can potentially delete a share, as the export_location was registered when trying to manage it and there is no way to tell at which point the manage operation fail. Even if they were renamed successfully and failed later (when creating the rename export), then deleting the share will delete the share and the user will lose all its data.

pkg/phase/executors/errors.go.message: We should follow the same pattern as with phases put it into separate package from executors package. executors/errors/errors.go or phase/errors/errors.go

> it can be done in a follow up PS
I have absolutely nothing against that, if you want to do it in follow-up it is up you. 
> it won't correspond with PS topic
It will correspond to the topic since you are moving errors from pkg/phase to avoid cyclic dependencies. Moving errors to the right place would definitely be relevant to the PS topic. I asked to move them to separate package, because you are already moving them. I just wanted to save us all some time.
> there is no explicit urgent necessity to do it right now 
Can't argue with that.

My main purpose in this PS was to clean up phase related errors, the errors added in this particular file was moved here from pkg/phase/errors.go because they have more relations to executors, not phases (ErrInvalidPhase - vice versa). Of course, I can do the same with executor errors and move them to separate pkg, but it seems a) it can be done in a follow up PS; b) it won't correspond with PS topic; and c) there is no explicit urgent necessity to do it right now (since we don't have crossing dependencies on executor's errors which could create cyclic import error).

We have also improved the drivers in the following ways, and may be we can mention that.

- The drivers can now work with multiple filesystem clusters. The filesystem to be used by manila can be specified by the driver option 'cephfs_filesystem_name'.

- The removal of a share will be quicker for the manila user. The ceph-mgr volumes module moves the share's content to a trash folder and purges the trash's contents (`rm -rf` of the backend CephFS subvolume/subtree) aysnchronously, whereas the ceph_volume_client library moves the share's content and purges the content synchronously.

The ceph_volume_client library creates a cephfs client session using 'cephfs_auth_id' to perform file system operations. We evict other cephfs client sessions using 'cephfs_auth_id' during setup to ensure that we have a unique instance of manila cephfs driver/ceph_volume_client.

1) Agreed. I have (hopefully) done that now in patchset 5.


2) But while we are talking about cleaning things up:

Potentially it might make sense to move the whole feature-by-feature config to use the same approach as the RBD volume driver: https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/volume/drivers/rbd.py

There a "regular" Rados client config file is referenced to initialize the client (https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/83e511e012b416aecd45136fd94779dcf466f2ed/cinder/volume/drivers/rbd.py#L464). Checking of ceph features required for certain toggles is then done directly on the client - https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/83e511e012b416aecd45136fd94779dcf466f2ed/cinder/volume/drivers/rbd.py#L407

This would remove all those individual features from cluttering the driver initialization and even allow new Ceph features to be added without those being added to the cinder-backup RBD driver (as long as there is no cinder-backup feature toggle related or required). Just like this very example of fast-diff here which could have been just via an external config file for the RBD client but a dedicated feature flag for cinder-backup.
not sure: I'm not sure but I think we still need to check the exclusive lock support anyways because I could forget to enable it in the conf and try fast-diff.

Thanks for looking into my patch!

Support for fast_diff depends on exclusive lock to be available for the RBD we talk to.
(see https://github.com/ceph/ceph/blob/master/doc/rbd/rbd-config-ref.rst#config-settings)

So in short: If the driver reports fast_diff to be supported we can implicitly assume exclusive lock to be supported as well.
As discussed during the weekly meeting, let's remove config option and use it always if RBD supports it

ansible/roles/monasca/tasks/check-contai.message: This is a bit odd and could trigger some corner cases. Suggest we use the storm role to do it instead, possibly as a separate destroy/cleanup command.

Agree that it would be more canonical to run it from the Storm role - the issue is that the Storm role won't run if the alerting pipeline is disabled and I didn't want the change to snowball into a large one (generic remove services). I could remove these steps, but it would seem a shame. Could you be convinced to keep it if the include_vars was more specific?

Yes, that is an issue. If this was a one-off migration to remove some unsupported services I would be more inclined to accept a fudge, but I expect this would be here forever?

With my scale/performance hat on I'm also thinking that this role executes on all hosts due to monasca-agent, so tasks are expensive.

Maybe a happy medium would be a specific command to disable the alerting pipeline?

/COMMIT_MSG.message: spelling
Done

Do you understand why this issue has been happening so much recently? Has something changed in SM to trigger this problem? It sounds like this issue would have been there since day one - why wouldn't we have seen these problems years ago?

This issue is related with timimg. SM starts a task (separated thread) to query hbsAgent for hbs cluster info (introduced 2 years ago). The first case was reported 6 months ago. There is no direct code change relate to the issue, but there is code change 6 months ago did change the execution timing https://opendev.org/starlingx/ha/commit/2d0fc9b6118c7c9dd69290aa133c223ad557e5ae
spelling

line is too long

service-mgmt/sm-db/src/sm_db_iterator.c.message: So there are no cases where the user of the iterator writes to the database?
There isn't current case iterator writes data back to database.
nit: this would be more clear with define of a READ_ONLY constant, or resuse of the SQLITE_OPEN_READONLY flag.

The sm_db_connect wrapper function is to hide detail of SQLite interfaces. It intents to  hide SQLITE declarations such as SQLITE_OPEN_READONLY. Also not sure it is worth to declare a new type to replace the bool type.

service-mgmt/sm/src/sm_main_event_handle.message: It would be better to 'revert' your instrumentation change separate from the fix update ?

> It would be better to 'revert' your instrumentation change separate from the fix update ?

I don't think that makes too big a different? Plus I will keep the change that allow systemd to recover SM process with 10 seconds delay.

service-mgmt/sm/src/sm_service_action_re.message: It appears the db would have been already been connected ... would removal of this sm_db_connect() in this state have been sufficient to remove an error trigger condition?

The common practice is each module maintains its own connection to db, open and close accordingly. This change doesn't want to change the practice. This change focuses on clean up unused connections and make sure only create writable connection when write permission is needed, in order to avoid the concurrent issue.
